channel.title: [Programming challenge] Find all subsets of a set

item.title: [Programming challenge] Find all subsets of a set
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“Yz85Racer, post:31, topic:461713”][code=Java] public static Set<Set> subsets(Set superset) {
Set<Set> subsets = new HashSet<Set>();
subsets.add(new HashSet());

    for (T e : superset) {
        Set<Set<T>> tmp = new HashSet<Set<T>>(subsets);
        for (Set<T> subset : tmp) {
            Set<T> ext = new HashSet<T>(subset);
            ext.add(e);
            subsets.add(ext);
        }
    }
    return subsets;
}[/code]

Noone posted one in Java yet I don’t think

Challenge required sorted output

item.source: [Programming challenge] Find all subsets of a set

item.title: [Programming challenge] Find all subsets of a set
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

Was bored, decided to do this

[code]
def static subset(T… vals) {
val size = vals.length

	val powerset = <Set<T>>newHashSet

	for (var bit = 0; bit < (1 << size); bit++) {
		val set = <T>newHashSet
		for (var index = 0; index < size; index++) {
			if ((bit >> index) % 2 == 1) {
				set += vals.get(index)
			}
		}
		powerset += set
	}

	return powerset.sortWith [ one, two |
		Integer.valueOf(one.size).compareTo(two.size)
	]
}[/code]

[[], [1], [2], [3], [4], [1, 2], [1, 3], [2, 3], [1, 4], [2, 4], [3, 4], [1, 2, 3], [1, 2, 4], [1, 3, 4], [2, 3, 4], [1, 2, 3, 4]]

Read full topic
item.source: [Programming challenge] Find all subsets of a set

item.title: [Programming challenge] Find all subsets of a set
item.dc:creator: @Uncalled Uncalled
item.description:
@Uncalled wrote:

def subsets[T](s : Set[T]) : Set[Set[T]] = if (s.size == 0) Set(Set()) else { val tailSubsets = subsets(s.tail); tailSubsets ++ tailSubsets.map(_ + s.head) }

Read full topic

item.source: [Programming challenge] Find all subsets of a set

item.title: [Programming challenge] Find all subsets of a set
item.dc:creator: @Vrunk Vrunk
item.description:
@Vrunk wrote:

def s(a)a.inject([[]]){|m,o|m+m.map{|e|e+[o]}}end # unsorted version

def s(a)(0..a.length).inject([]){|m,o|m.push *a.combination(o)}end # sorted version (but not guaranteed)

def s(a)(0..a.length).inject([]){|m,o|m.push *a.combination(o).sort}end # sorted version (guaranteed)

a=*1..4;p *s(a) # test for any of them

Read full topic

item.title: [Programming challenge] Find all subsets of a set
item.dc:creator: @CodeForFame CodeForFame
item.description:
@CodeForFame wrote:

[quote=“The Enforcer, post:15, topic:461713”]Scripting languages seem to have all these fancy features that enable solving this task in just a few lines. I benchmarked generating combinations C(n, k).

Input data.

n = 50
k = [5, 45, 6, 44]
set = [0 .. 49]

Just generating combinations.

Language: C++, k = 5, 5ms
Language: C++, k = 45, 102ms
Language: C++, k = 6, 41ms
Language: C++, k = 44, 681ms
Language: python, k = 5, 143ms
Language: python, k = 45, 550ms
Language: python, k = 6, 1109ms
Language: python, k = 44, 3908ms

Generating and saving combinations to memory.

Language: C++ T**, k = 5, 123ms
Language: C++ T**, k = 45, 300ms
Language: C++ T**, k = 6, 967ms
Language: C++ T**, k = 44, 2137ms
Language: C++ std::vector<std::vector<T>>, k = 5, 156ms
Language: C++ std::vector<std::vector<T>>, k = 45, 452ms
Language: C++ std::vector<std::vector<T>>, k = 6, 1263ms
Language: C++ std::vector<std::vector<T>>, k = 44, 3338ms
Language: python, k = 5, 483ms
Language: python, k = 45, 1420ms
Language: python, k = 6, 3805ms
Language: python, k = 44, MemoryError

In the C++ cases T means the type of the element in a combination, during benchmarking it was an unsigned int. T** is a two-dimensional raw array, std::vector<std::vector> - you’ll understand. It seems that python is only good for fancy 1-3-liners, but struggles when serious computing power is needed. Below is the python benchmarking code, my experience with python is minimal and it was several years ago - so if anyone thinks it can be sped up, feel free to do it. The C++ code, however, will remain private as NSA has contacted me with a wish to buy it.

[code=python]
import itertools
import time

a = []
b = []
n = 50
k = 45
l = 0
for i in range(n):
a.append(i)

startTime = time.clock()
for i in itertools.combinations(a, k):
b.append(i)
#pass
timeTaken = time.clock();
print(len(b))
print(timeTaken)
[/code][/quote]You’re not taking into account that they’re doing two completely different things… The Python version is creating an iterator, that only computes the values on-demand, which is using a completely different algorithm. Basically, the Python version is built for memory conservation and yours is built for speed.

Furthermore, I think it’s a given that Python will be slower than C++ for things of this nature…

BTW Scala isn’t a scripting language and it’s the shortest solution posted, so far. Performance of it could be much improved if it the algorithm was changed, and makes use of parallel collections. At which point I’m pretty sure it would be the fastest/loc (with properly formatted code) for decent sized sets.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

[quote=“veer, post:16, topic:461713”][quote] const std::size_t subsetsSize = 1 << setSize;[/quote][/quote]

const std::size_t subsetsSize = std::size_t(1) << setSize;
If setSize > sizeof(std::size_t) * CHAR_BIT - 1, then too bad.

item.title: [Programming challenge] Find all subsets of a set
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

Scripting languages seem to have all these fancy features that enable solving this task in just a few lines. I benchmarked generating combinations C(n, k).

Input data.

n = 50
k = [5, 45, 6, 44]
set = [0 .. 49]

Just generating combinations.

Language: C++, k = 5, 5ms
Language: C++, k = 45, 102ms
Language: C++, k = 6, 41ms
Language: C++, k = 44, 681ms
Language: python, k = 5, 143ms
Language: python, k = 45, 550ms
Language: python, k = 6, 1109ms
Language: python, k = 44, 3908ms

Generating and saving combinations to memory.

Language: C++ T**, k = 5, 123ms
Language: C++ T**, k = 45, 300ms
Language: C++ T**, k = 6, 967ms
Language: C++ T**, k = 44, 2137ms
Language: C++ std::vector<std::vector<T>>, k = 5, 156ms
Language: C++ std::vector<std::vector<T>>, k = 45, 452ms
Language: C++ std::vector<std::vector<T>>, k = 6, 1263ms
Language: C++ std::vector<std::vector<T>>, k = 44, 3338ms
Language: python, k = 5, 483ms
Language: python, k = 45, 1420ms
Language: python, k = 6, 3805ms
Language: python, k = 44, MemoryError

In the C++ cases T means the type of the element in a combination, during benchmarking it was an unsigned int. T** is a two-dimensional raw array, std::vector<std::vector> - you’ll understand. It seems that python is only good for fancy 1-3-liners, but struggles when serious computing power is needed. Below is the python benchmarking code, my experience with python is minimal and it was several years ago - so if anyone thinks it can be sped up, feel free to do it. The C++ code, however, will remain private as NSA has contacted me with a wish to buy it.

import itertools
import time

a = []
b = []
n = 50
k = 45
l = 0
for i in range(n):
    a.append(i)


startTime = time.clock()
for i in itertools.combinations(a, k):
    b.append(i)
    #pass
timeTaken = time.clock();
print(len(b))
print(timeTaken)

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma

powerset :: [a] -> [[a]] powerset [] = [[]] powerset (x:xs) = ps ++ map (x:) ps where ps = powerset xs

No one said it had to take a set that was chosen by the user, in that case nor does t4’s.

It does, actually.

it’s hard coded as is his… the bigger issue with his is he hardcoded the length. i was lazy and didn’t add user input.
[/quote]It simply says write an algorithm, not write an application that accepts user input.[/quote]
an algorithm is supposed to reusable ;). this discussion over user input vs hard-coded list is dumb… it really doesn’t matter. ps, i never was disputing you.

[quote=“CodeForFame, post:12, topic:461713”][quote author=t4 link=topic=564663.msg4110970#msg4110970 date=1348517173]
